text:
Thank you for inviting me. I think I was thinking
about it, and last time I visited was 10 years ago.

So lots of things have changed. And today, I'm
going to talk about, I was thinking of what should
I name the title for this talk.

And I really wanted
to raise a question, where are the field robots? And I believe
they're in your labs. And well, how do we get them out
of there and into the fields?

So I'm going to talk about that. I'm going to talk
broadly about my work. That includes the work
at the university,

as well as with the startups. I've tried to
synergize those things without causing
a lot of overlap,

and that's very true. I think I believe very much in
creating algorithms and creating

ideas in the lab,
but I also believe very much in getting those
out and into the field.

And nice to see Rajan
here, who worked with me back in the day at UIUC. So originally I'm from India,
and like many people's ancestors

in a couple of
generations ago, my dad used to have a farm which was
spectacularly loss generating.

And he stopped doing it. Along the way, I've been at
many places, Georgia Tech, MIT,

Oklahoma State. And I've been involved in
entrepreneurial activities all the way through.

I was a part of
my advisor startup at Georgia Tech called
Adaptive Flight, and then these two startups, which very
graciously folded later on.

And then now, EarthSense,
which has been going pretty well for a while now.

I'm an aerospace
engineer by training. And when I was growing
up as a little child,

I wanted to go to Mars. And then I started studying
aerospace engineering and got more into
drones and robotics.

And I started realizing
that there's a lot of things that you have to do on Earth. So what do you do
when you go to Mars?

You have to
terraform the planet. Well, there's a lot of
terraforming that we need to do here on Earth. So I started thinking about
how do I build a program that

is focused on doing that? And so that's what
my group does. We work on autonomous robots,
particularly field robots.

And we are a diverse
set of individuals from computer science,
mechanical engineering,

electrical engineering,
ag engineering, and all over the place. And our main goal is
to create at the lab

the science that drives
robotics, and then with our partners, the robots
that actually go out there

and cause changes. So the way I look at field
robotics or robotics overall

is this triangle. You have perception,
planning, and control.

And at the middle
of it is the system. And one of the key things
that I really believe in

is that all of these things
have to work together. And in order for them to
work in the field, which

is an unstructured,
unpredictable, dynamic environment, they
have to be in a way

that they adapt and
they work together. So this is an example
of some of the work that I used to do back
when I was at Georgia Tech.

It's an aircraft that is flying,
and then suddenly in mid-air, it throws half of its wing off.

What happens? This is the reason why we
have pilots in airplanes. What happens when such
emergencies come up?

So how can we create
autonomy algorithms that adapt to these
changes, that work

through these
uncertain environments and bring that AI that's
on there to the extreme? So back in the day when
I did this, a lot of it

was model-based. So using predictive models of
how the aircraft would behave,

planning and doing
control-based off of that. And you see it actually
stays in the air and enters this
stable limit cycle.

This is the Georgia
Tech twin star aircraft, which has about a 2-meter
wingspan and keeps flying with

half the wing off. And with half the wing off,
the half of the aileron is off. But the journey for me
since then has been,

how do you bring this
adaptability into robots so that they can work in
real world environments

and deal with real challenges
and do useful things? And then overall,
I'm not the only one.

Of course, there's a
pretty large community that works on field robots. And when you think
of field robots, you think of these
types of things,

legged robots, bipedal
robot, driving robots. I've been a part of
several workshops.

And I think it's pretty
clear that field robots hold the key to a lot of problems
facing sustainability.

So obviously, electric
ride share, now that's pretty much on the way here.

Climate-smart construction,
sustainable agriculture, which I'll talk about,
and I'll talk a little bit

about sustainable solar. But I purposefully picked these
pictures because you see there,

there's these humanoid
robots trying to do things. So just as silly as it is to
have a humanoid drive a car

for your autonomous
driving, I want to make the point that the
robots that actually end up

being successful and actually
end up being working, may not look anything
like the robots

that most people
think of, and really have to be a product or
co-design of the task

and the software together. And a lot of this is
actually inspired,

when I was growing
up as an academic or as a graduate student,
is inspired by the work

by Andrew Ng and the first
aircraft that did the flips.

And of course, Sebastian, of
whom I heard a lot about at MIT

because the team that
competed against Stanford was MIT, which didn't win.

[CHUCKLES] But a lot of the
effort that these early robotics

engineers put in was towards
co-designing hardware software so that we have reliable robots.

So here are my main
points that I'm going to make through this talk. So where are the field robots?

They're stuck in labs. How do we get them
out of the labs? We need to think
about scaling up.

We need to think about
continuous learning and adaptation on the fly. We need to think about
performance in the open world,

not in structured
environments and common sense. So towards that,
the journey to date

has been discovering
a philosophy. And this philosophy, I
called this philosophy the TERRA philosophy.

So the T stands for terrain
adaptability or task adaptability, E for
energy efficiency,

R for robustness, reliability,
and affordability. So what I'm going
to do now is I'm

going to show you four or
five of examples of robots that we have created
while we were discovering

this philosophy, describe to
you the journey and the impacts that these robots are
right now causing.

So first, we'll start
with agriculture. So agriculture, as
you know, California is huge in agriculture,
one of the largest

agriculture-producing state. The agriculture here is
quite different than that in the Midwest.

In the Midwest, we do a lot of
corn and soybean agriculture. And the key tenet of the
agriculture robotics work

that I'm doing is that there
is this labor bottleneck that's causing unsustainable
practices to be used.

And the idea is that robotics
and AI will help alleviate those labor bottlenecks.

So this is an interesting
paper by Foley that appeared in Science. And it talks about what is the
cost of producing food today

compared to the amount of
food that we're growing. And you might have
heard something about how we're going
to be 10 billion people

in the next few years. And that's going to
be a big, big problem. And in all honesty, we need
to increase the amount of food

that we're growing. But we also need to bring
in control the cost of that.

I'm talking about the
environmental cost. So greenhouse gas emission,
biodiversity loss, water pollution,
water withdrawals.

So this is called
sustainable intensification. So how do we do this? So one of the most unsustainable
crops that's out there is corn.

So there's 200 million acres
of it in all of the I states. And it's what we call a
large scale monoculture.

So you take large
swaths of land, you clear it off everything
else and just plant corn. And because you're
moving the prairie away

from its natural
state of equilibrium, you have to put a lot of
chemicals in to make that work. So herbicides,
fungicides, fertilizers

But the problem is that
this system of large scale monocultures, not only is it
unsustainable, but it's failing.

So you might have heard of
a pesticide in your waters, but there's also a huge
challenge with the herbicides

that folks are using. So the weeds are becoming
herbicide-resistant. And this is not
anything mythical.

You actually see it now. If you drive down in
Champaign, a few years ago, we didn't have a lot
of weeds visible.

But now, close to the
end of the season, you see these weeds popping
up out of these soybean crop

and to a level where sometimes
it's impossible to harvest. So this, according
to some people, is a real doomsday situation.

The large equipment that we use
to enable these large farms. So a normal farmer in the
Midwest will have 2,500 acres

of land under control. It is not contiguous land. It is parcels of land that are
distributed all over the place.

And the only way they
get anything done is by using these
very large machines. Whereas these machines
cause soil compaction,

they cause erosion, they
cause nutrient loss. And on the other
side of the world, if you look at another very
unsustainable crop, which

I'll talk a little bit
about, which is palm oil, crops like that cause
significant deforestation

and loss of biodiversity. And even with all of this, this
is just with corn and soybean,

the trends are that our
yields are not actually matching the demand.

So one way to address
this challenge is by adding new
options for farmers.

So today farmers can
either use manual labor or use large tractors. Manual labor is great
for small scale farming.

Large tractors are great for
very large scale monocultures. There's really
nothing in between. So one of the ideas that we
started thinking about about six

or seven years ago was, can we
use a number of small robots that can work together and
do things that are today

not possible due to
unavailability of labor, such as phenotyping, mechanical
weeding, cover cropping?

And I'll talk a little bit
about some of these things. And this idea of robots in
agriculture is not very new.

People have been talking about
this for at least 10, 15 years, but it's very challenging. And even though there's a
number of companies out there

that are trying to
do it, the problems are really hard because
the scales are very large,

the field is very messy. And whatever data
there is, is not really representative
of what actually

happens in the environment. So where are the ag robots? So even though you see a number
of these companies coming up

and robots coming
up, we haven't really seen a large scale adoption. And if you really
peel the onion,

and there's a lot of
interesting work on this, everything boils down to cost. So we cannot use the same ways
or same methods that we're using

for autonomous driving, in which
we're using a lot of sensors and oversensing the problem,
mapping everything out.

We have to find ways in which we
can reduce the cost while also making the robots work.

So this is something
that we came up with, this idea of levels
of autonomy for robots.

So we need to grow
up the levels. But as we go up every
level, and about level three

is when we have what
some people call the MVP, the minimum viable
product, because you're

using a team of robots
to basically get the work of a
single tractor done.

You need to, also at the same
time, bring the cost down. So now I'll give you
the first example of how

we've been trying to do that. And this robot is
called TerraSentia. And we have made
about 80 of these.

And I think you were
involved in this. And these are actually
deployed in the field.

So corn. which is everywhere in the
Midwest, turns out it's actually not a natural
crop in the sense

that if you go back through
the history of agriculture, you won't find a natural
ancestor of corn.

What you find is this
thing called teosinte, which looks nothing like corn. But the Native American
people in South America

selectively bred teosinte with
other crops to create corn. And there's a very
interesting article

on this in the New York Times. And it turns out that only
about 3,000 years ago, the latest varieties of
corn were created like that.

And right now, even
under the North Pole, the modern varieties
of corn are stored.

So in case we get
hit by a meteorite, we don't have to go
3,000 years back.

But of course, that
pace of breeding, it cannot keep up with
what's happening today.

So the seeds in a large-- the only way you can make a
single farmer deal with 2,500

acres is to create seeds
that are super adapted to the environment. So in India, this is a
joke that I used to make.

In India, if a bug eats
a plant, the plant dies.

But in the Midwest,
if a bug tries to eat a properly bred corn
plant, the bug will die.

[LAUGHS] So that's the idea. But the pace is just
not matching up.

So in order to feed
the world, we really need to accelerate this pace. So to do this, modern
crop scientists

use a technique called
genome-wide association, along with other techniques. And what happens here is that
you sequence all the genomes,

and you measure the
environment, and you're looking for the patterns
in the genomics that

represent specific
phenotypes, for example, disease-resistant yield. And once you find
them, then your job

is to then use
techniques like CRISPR to then create the crop that
accelerates those traits.

But we don't have a model. We don't have a
simulation of plants. So the only way you can do that
is by running very large scale

trials. So what these companies do is
they run hundreds of thousands

of acres of trials. This is one example
of a 90-acre trial, in which if you look carefully,
this is sorghum trial.

Each of these blocks, I
don't know if you can see, there are blocks here, is a
different variety of the crop.

And they are being compared
against each other. And the challenge is in
measuring all of this.

So you get quantitative
data so that you know which ones are doing better. And today all of those
measurements are manual.

And this results in what we
call the phenotyping bottleneck. So these folks are
counting, measuring stem height, stem width.

These are really difficult
things to measure and take forever time. So you can automate that
using gantries or drones.

But neither of those see
under the canopy, which is where robots come in, but
most robots are over the canopy.

So in 2017, we introduced
these 3D-printed robot called TerraSentia, which won the Best
Paper Award at the Robotics

Science and Systems Conference. And the idea was
really this small robot

that can go under the
canopy, and use machine learning techniques to
basically do simple phenotype.

In this case, it was counting. And the genesis
of that robot was that before we started
working on that robot,

these were the kinds of
robots that were out there. So this is a robot that was
made before I came to UIUC.

It's a tracked
robot, and people are using all these best practices.

So people thought,
well, you have to make a tracked robot
because it's the field. But you see here, this
robot drags that plant down.

You have to put a
mast on it because you want to see down there. You have to put the
most expensive sensor that you can find on it.

But the reality
was that while that was an expensive and
interesting robot, it actually didn't do the job
that it was supposed to do.

So that's where, as we learned
from the world of drones

that miniaturizing a helicopter
was not the solution, we had to come up with a
drone, which is not something

that a human would fly in
because it's impossible to fly until you put an IMU on it. So a student of mine then
came up with this idea, well,

why are we trying
to do all of this? Why don't we just take our drone
and make it run on the ground?

Obviously you cannot
fly it through there because the endurance
just wouldn't be there. So we came up with
this 3D-printed robot.

And I think it was just a
very basic idea of just taking

those motors and
flipping them down and each of them
having their own motor, and there was no other
moving part other than that,

and then putting
a camera on there to see how well that works.

Who knows Steve Blank? Anybody know Steve
Blank, Lean Startup? Stanford person who created
this whole philosophy

of Lean Startup. So I cover I-Corps project, NSF
I-Corps project, and we went

and we engaged with customers. And we said we made 30 of
these 3D-printed robots, and we gave them to customers.

And we said, OK, we'll
go use them in the field. We'll see how well that works. And literally, some of
them melted in the field

because field environments
are very difficult. So at around the same time,
this company EarthSense

that I co-founded
took over that project and became a technology partner
in the ARPA-E TerraMap project,

and created this robot
called TerraSentia, in which Rajan was a part
of creating the drivetrain.

So this was a very
different field robot compared to the ones
that were out there.

It was made with hub motors. So each wheel was
itself a motor.

There was no connections
other than that. So directly you connected
your arm to the wheels.

These motors, because
their hub was contactless, brushless hub motors,
they can go through water.

They can go through snow. They can go through all
kinds of different terrain. And the robot was
extremely tough,

as is shown in this example. So this was, I think the 2020
or 2021 version of that robot.

We iterated across three years. And every year, we tried
to improve the robot,

and finally bringing it
to this level of maturity. So this is one of our engineers,
just loading up the robot

with some weight. And the robot itself weighs
no more than 20 kilos. Then he's sitting on it.

And then the robot pulls
this 400 Series tractor.

So I think it was
very interesting getting into the design
space there and figuring out

how we can use electric
propulsion to make sure that we pack a lot of power
in very tiny machines.

So that's great. That was one part. The other part was trying to get
these robots to be autonomous. So the standard
way of doing that

is with global
positioning system, GPS. And it works great on John Deere
true track and Trimble's GPS

systems because they have
clear view of the sky. But once you start
going under the canopy--

and we did a lot
of work on this.  A number of papers that
one of my students wrote,

who's now at University of
Oklahoma as a professor, was figuring out these traction
coefficients in real time

and using them to
improve the control, and using techniques like
model-predictive control

and receding horizon
estimators, to really improve the accuracy of GPS.

But the problem is once you
go under the plant canopy, whereas with a real
time kinematic RTK GPS,

you're supposed to get under
two centimeters accuracy, the accuracy drops
to 40 centimeters

because the signals
bounce off of the plants. So we started in
about 2019 working

on how do we solve this
problem using extra reception? And we posed this problem as a
row-following behavior problem.

So using a single
sensor, can we figure out the distance to the row
and the angle to the row?

And in a setting like here,
this is a LiDAR point cloud,

so the LiDAR is here. Again, we're trying to
reduce the cost of the LiDAR. So it's $1,000 LiDAR.

And these are all
the plants here. So you see it's a completely
messy point cloud. Whereas if you
try to drive here,

you'll get a very nice line
on which you can fit a line. So fitting the lines on
that LiDAR point cloud

was one of the first key
challenges that we had to solve. And that's explained
in this paper here.

And we came up with a
method that was basically a accelerated form
of line fitting

in the presence of outliers. And then we created that
and put it onto the robots.

So this is an example
of me giving that robot a hard time as it's
driving down the field
with this algorithm on it.

And this is where we started
forming this philosophy that, OK, you can create a paper,
you can write a paper,

you can create an algorithm,
but the real test is to go out there, and
can you kick the robot? So that's what I
tell my students.

Your robot has to be kickable
before you can graduate. So here you can see it's a
very tiny sensor right here.

And the plants
are all around it. And with this, EarthSense,
this was just a part of it.

Of course, the company did a
whole other set of development that is proprietary. But they created
this first product

that started to make sense
in the space of agriculture. So this is a high throughput
phenotyping product.

It's a robot that goes
through the rows of corn. It's detecting and measuring
individual ears of corn.

And then reporting
back this data, essentially a plan-by-plan
basis, to the breeders,

in a front end system
that looks like this. So this is a National Science
Foundation project called Crops.

And this is a field map. So each of those plots
represent the grid that I showed you before. And that's the plant
height, ear height,

measuring at the same
time, four traits, and across different
time stamps.

So you can get a full high
throughput view of that. And we have a paper
hopefully that

will come out by the end
of maybe early spring, that shows how well that works
across multiple years

on data with a
very large company. So taking that same idea,
this is just measuring,

and it is limited
to crop breeding, we wanted to bring
that idea to farmers. So in the Midwest, the
agriculture is very seasonal.

So we have right now,
when I left Chicago, the temperature was
18 degrees Fahrenheit.

So it's freezing. And there's basically
nothing that lives. So from basically November
all the way into March,

we leave these 200 million
acres entirely bare. And then before planting happens
in around June or late May,

weeds come up, and
the soil degenerates, and all kinds of things happen. But there's a way, and this soil
could be doing useful things.

So you can grow
cover crops on it, and cover crops can
do a number of things. They can sequester carbon,
they can fix nitrogen,

they can hold nitrogen
that's excess, and they can break
up compaction. So different types of cover
crops can do different things.

Now there's also cover crops
that can be used for harvesting. They can create biomass that can
be used to create sustainable

aviation fuel, for example. But most farmers are
not able to do it. So this is around Thanksgiving.

If you try to land
in Champaign, you see what I call the
corn and soybean desert. It's just acres and
acres of bare land.

And the problem is that
they harvest somewhere around September. And if they try to get cover
crops planted after that,

the sunlight days
are really not there. So by November, it
starts to get cold, and they can't really do this.

So we had this idea,
what if we created a robot that could go through
the canopy and broadcast seeds?

So using the same
kind of technology that we were using for
broadcast seed so we can have cover crop planting
done as early

as August in standing corn. And with a lot of
economic analysis,

we can show that it can be
done at a much lower cost. But the problem is you need
to bring the cost of the robot

further down. And you need to make
it more reliable. So LiDAR-based autonomy
is just not enough.

So we had to change the sensors
and think about using cameras. So these cameras cost $30,
whereas the LiDARs cost about

$1,000. But that's a very
challenging problem because fields are
really messy when you try

to do it with monocular vision. So we work together to create
a method called CropFollow.

And Arun, who is about to
graduate, worked on this. And here the idea
was, we thought about many different
ways of doing it.

The one way you could do
it is using techniques like reinforcement learning,
so where you basically

learn everything
from scratch and try to see how that
whole setup works. But the problem with that is
it's really difficult to debug.

And then in this high mix, low
volume manufacturing setup, these robots are
individually very different.

And because of that,
it becomes very hard to find where
the issues are. And of course, we had a
fully working system also.

So what we did is that we just
swapped this distance and angle

estimation with vision. And we said that,
can we find distance

to the row and angle to the
row with a single vision? So basically have a single
vision, single camera,

a monocular camera. And image from the
camera goes in, it goes through
a neural network, and it predicts the
distance to the row

and the angle with
respect to the row. So we started doing
this in about 2019.

And back then, we did it with
labeling, heavily supervised

learning. So we labeled about 26,000
images using all kinds of techniques, where you
can correct the image.

When you don't see
the horizon, we used the plant as the way
of seeing the horizon. Measure the roll
and pitch, and then

get basically a good estimate
of where crossing points are.

And then we used that
to train this model. And then we started testing
it in the real world, and it worked really well. So these are some examples of
this vision-based autonomy.

You can see the terrain
is really challenging. And the robot is
able to tolerate

early season, late
season, a small curve, and through
significant occlusions.

And so we deployed this
and this is now Arun. And you can tell that he's
ready to graduate because he's

starting to kick his robot now. He's a lot more gentler, I know. Also the there's a
number of other things

that were also changed. As you can see, the robot is
also controlling its speed now.

So there's a little
planning module on there, which is trying
to control the speed as well as the angle of
the robot to make sure
that it's going on its path.

Can you see the plants? This is early season soybean. So obviously, the LiDAR isn't
working because the plants

are not as tall as the LiDAR. And then after a while, the
robot will enter in early season corn, it's going straight.

This is at the Farm of
the Future at Illinois.
So anyway, let me see. Push it forward a bit.

So just seamlessly transitions
into early season corn and continues to go.

So this was great. And then we took it, this
and several other methods,

we tried to do a large
scale experiment with it. And then we started finding
out that even though everything

worked great in the paper and
we were able to get, again, very large sets of validations. And it was an RSS paper,
25 kilometers, I think.

The fact is that
when you started to deploy it beyond that, we
started to see a lot of issues.

So one of the issues was
that the environment changes. There's really no
uncertainty predictions

because the environment
changes, you basically end up with a domain shift.

And because the
cameras on these robots are differently
calibrated and installed

with slight defects,
what works on one robot doesn't work on the other. There's little
biases that creep up.

So in last year or
this year, 2024, we published another
paper called CropFollow++,

in which now instead of
doing the full angle to row, we're basically creating a
confidence estimate of where

the horizons are. So its 3 points, the
end of the horizon point, the two points
here at the side.

And then combine that with AI
to detect failures and recover from failures when they happen.

So this is an example
of that happening. So there were two
sets of papers. So one was the 2024 RSS, and
the other was a [INAUDIBLE]

2023 paper. We put that together, and that
is working really well now.

And that's what creates
this kind of an idea. So you have a robot which can
go through standing rows of corn

and distribute seeds
of corn together. So these new types of
distribution methods

that are now coming out, each
robot can cover nine rows. So four rows and one
side and four rows

on the other side and
the row that it's in. So each robot can cover
nine rows at a time. So if you have 10
robots, you can

cover 90 rows at the same time. So driving at about
a meter per second,

these robots can
get the whole field planted in less than five hours,
which then becomes a whole field

the size of 100 acres. So that starts to now then
compete against thing. And by the time you
harvest, there's

already a standing
cover crop there. So this is a very
iconic picture.

The harvester has
just gone through, and the cover crops
already has emerged. So now you have, at
the Farm of the Future

we did an experiment comparing
robots versus tractors. And you can see by May,
by spring, the cover

crop that's planted with robots
is really robust and healthy. And we get a really
nice benefits

from these types of crops. We have a large grant
now to try and scale this

up with a target of many
thousands of acres next year,

and trying to really bring
this technology to fruition.

Now I'll talk about another
example of the TERRA philosophy with a robot called TerraMax.

And this is now all the way on
the other side of the world, in Malaysia, in palm
oil plantations.

So palm oil is one of
the most consumed oil. So apparently, 50% of
supermarket products

have palm oil, less so
nowadays because of all kinds of issues in the US.

But if you go to
Asia, I think even Cadbury's chocolate has
palm oil, and in my opinion
it tastes better. So palm oil is tasteless.

It's a vegetable oil. It can be used pretty well. But the issue with
it is that it's a huge contributor
to deforestation,

and it has very serious
labor challenges. Basically significant
issues with contract labor

And a key problem with
palm oil, especially in places like Malaysia,
is that labor is just

very difficult to get and
very difficult to retain. So, for example, 20%
of palm oil growers

are able to hire only
20% of the-- sorry. Palm oil growers are only
able to hire 20% of the labor

that they needed in 2022. And the losses are just in
many billions of dollars. And people often wonder, why are
we so worried about this anyway?

What's the big deal
about palm oil? It's all the way in Asia. So these are two very
revealing charts.

So here, this is the
amount of palm oil yield that you can get per hectare.

And you can see that it's crazy,
compared to all these other oils

that you can get. Soybean oil is here. It's three times
that of soybean oil.

And in the amount
of land that you need to meet the global demand,
so basically 8.6% of the land

under palm cultivation
meets 36% of production. Whereas with soybean,
we have almost 40%

of the land under production,
and we are only meeting 25%.

And if you think of
sustainable aviation fuel, palm oil is really the
only way to get there.

Because we can meet
global fuel demand with about 84 million
hectares of palm oil, which is really off the chart
compared to all the other ways.

So it really isn't any option. The only real option
left is to try and make

palm oil production more
sustainable and more fair

in terms of labor. Now, many countries are
trying to reduce the area

under palm oil cultivation. Malaysia is in the forefront. They have managed to

will be used for agriculture. And the idea here is, can we use
robots and AI to make production

better, for example,
using things like precision fertilization,
precision spraying, and over time,
harvesting transport?

So for this purpose, we created
a robot called TerraMax. Our TerraMax is a
completely different robot.

It's a 500-kilo robot that's
much larger than our other

robots. It still uses the same
types of techniques. So individual wheel motors, no
variable transmission shaft.

So there's no transmission. So the two wheels can operate
completely independent of each other.

They each have their
own suspension. It can tackle really
challenging terrain. And the middle part
is open for putting

different types of payloads. So in this case, it's
a fertilizer bin.

And then you'll see that it
does some spreading right here, fertilizer spreading. It's a fully electric
battery-operated robot,

that we are learning
a lot about optimizing the motors to do this. And just as a comparison,
that's TerraSentia,

and that's TerraMax. It's a totally different robot. So in September,
I was in Malaysia,

and we managed to do 100
hectares, 102 hectares in seven days. It was a challenge
that was set forth

by the industry to
see how scalable or will this technology work. And it was quite exciting.

And here's just some snippets. And of course, I think from
a research perspective,

these robots use some
of the techniques that I talked about, but of
course, way more than that.

So they ended up
using a technique in which this type
of rule following is combined with basically
semantic segmentation.

And large scale
semantic segmentation combined with the
rule following creates

a pretty good understanding
for the robot where it is. That's combined with the
GPS data that it's getting.

And then you saw in
that video that it's detecting individual trees,
distance to the trees, and then executing maneuvers.

And it's quite challenging
because there's a ditch right here. There's a ditch on

It's quite challenging,
this environment. But it seems it's been
doing pretty well.

We also have remote
monitoring systems in place so that we can keep an

and then get this robot
to drive autonomously. And these all, everything here
I'm showing you is autonomous.

So that is the benefit of
not having a transmission. So basically, wheels
are totally imbalanced,

but the robot is able to
go through some really tough terrain. So that's my engineer.

She's just delighted
that it tackled that. And it rains every
day in Malaysia.

So you can't avoid
muddy puddles. But of course, even with
that, the robots fall down.

And one of the big lessons that
we've learned now is that you really cannot try to make the
whole system fully autonomous.

You really have to think
about increasing throughput. So here the robot
fell into the ditch,

and it was pulled
out by the tractor and immediately returned
and resumed work.

It was not a showstopper
by any means.

But essentially, I think one
of the big philosophies that's coming out of it, and this
is after completing the 100

hectares, is that
you really have to find ways in which humans and
robots work together, as opposed

to just imagining that robots

not there yet. Because let's say you put the

can find, you still need
somebody to clean it eventually, unless you put a

cleaning system,

then the cleaning system breaks. So I think, really, we have to
start thinking about robotics as an assistive technology.

So the other thing
I'll talk about now is some of our work in
broader field robotics

and just algorithms
for driving robots, and this method called WayFast. So you see here this tractor
driver, just using their eyes,

is basically pulling
this very, very, very heavy truck on this
completely muddy terrain.

So if you try to do that with
just using GPS or something,

it's just not going to work. You have to have experience
built in and learning in real time adaptation
to deal with that.

So we've been thinking about
how to encode that in software. And one way of
doing that is what

we call WayFast, which
is waypoint-free adaptive navigation.

So basically, you give
only a single waypoint where the robot has to go. And the robot gets data from
its sensors, essentially

stereo cameras, and creates
a traversability and traction map just based off of that data,
just like a human would do.

So this is an
example of-- so this is a fully self-supervised
method that basically takes

in an image and creates a
traction map, which then becomes a cost function for a
controller that then generates

a path for the robot. So the way we do this is we
start with a standard robot

model. And that's really cool
because we can easily swap this model whenever
the robot changes,

so the system is
pretty scalable, and we add to it these
traction parameters that we talked about before.

We estimate these traction
parameters in real time, and then that becomes
the labels for the images

that the robot creates. So in the training time,
the robot is driving around, it's estimating the traction
as it's driving around.

And that data is correlated
back with images. Those images are then
used in the exploration

stage for training. So here, for example, you can
see as you're going around, the robot is driven and
it hits different things.

And the traction
that it experiences is encoded by itself.

Then you take an RGBD image, and
you create a traversability map using that data. That traversability map
becomes a cost function

for the model
predictive controller, and that creates the actions
that drives the robot.

And so you see
some examples here. So white is traversable
or with good traction.

And dark is not
with good traction. So you can see here
the robot clearly can say that snow is not as
traversable as clear terrain.

Similarly with trees,
and not only that, it also creates a
boundary around it because it knows once it
hits it, it will get stuck.

And remember, none of
this is with labeling. Whereas the other, the
first bit I was showing you was all with labeling.

This is all happening,
but the robot is doing this all by itself. And this is in real
time, an example

of how the traversability map
looks like as the robot is driving around.

And you can see, these are the
areas that are not traversable. And then these nice
behaviors emerge.

So the robot knows to detect
and to avoid the tree. And that's, I guess,
fairly geometric.

But the other
interesting thing is that obstacles that
are not geometric, for example this ditch,
it knows to avoid that

based on the visual data. And then in this case, it knows
that it can go through grass

because grass is traversable. It doesn't really lose
any traction there. But when it comes to the
tree, it has to avoid it.

But on the other hand,
if it was using a LiDAR, grass would look exactly
as untraversable as a tree.

And so more recently, we have
then tried to take a batch

of data in real time also,
a sequence of images, feed it into the network

traversability map
around the robot. So this is what
the robot creates, a bird's eye view traversability
map as the robot is driving.

And these are all the
different trajectories that it's thinking about,
and picking one of them.

And you can get some
really cool behaviors. Again, it knows it
can go through grass

because it doesn't

and even though

So that the robot can plan, if

with respect to that.

Let's see. We have only a few minutes left. And then this is
the last bit that I

want to talk about,
the philosophy again of hybrid soft manipulation.

So today's robots, tractors are
really good for low dexterous

tasks, but they
scale up very well. Humans are really good
for small scale tasks.

They have a large
level of dexterity. And robots that we
have today are really

not good at either of them. So the goal is to
try and create robots

that can have high
level of dexterity, as well as scale up well. So towards that,
we've been thinking

about how to create
different types of robots.

I've been working with a friend
of mine, Girish Krishnan, who's a professor at UIUC, as well as
Mattia Ghazala and Sarah, who

is the expert in
polycultures, to create new robotic concepts
that would work well

in a cluttered setting,
like a polyculture, in which different varieties of
plants are planted together

so that they can grow together. And so these arms
are essentially, they're called freeze.

They're basically tubes
wrapped around with a filament. And each of them is
wrapped in a different way,

so that when you pressure it,
they bend in a particular way. So by controlling the
pressure and the wrappings

on the different
types of tubes, you can create muscle-like structure
and bend these things any which way.

In 2020, we had a paper at
RSS, in which we basically

combined the arm, the
free arm, with a rigid arm

to create a hybrid manipulator. So the idea was
that, if the berry

or if the target is not within
the reach of the rigid arm, then you move the soft arm out
and/or whatever, and bend it

in any which way to get it. And the reason to do that is
because the rigid arm is really much faster.

It's very fast. You can move it really fast, but
it doesn't have the dexterity. While the soft arm can reach
all these different places,

but it doesn't have the speed. So can we combine it together? And I'll just show
you some results

that aren't yet published,
but hopefully soon will be, about just trying to get
these hybrid manipulators

to work in an intelligent way. So you must have seen a lot of
this type of work with rigid

manipulators, where robots
are detecting objects, creating 3D representations,
and picking things up.

And there's a lot of
very interesting thing, in which these are also
connected with a large language models.

But we want to do that,
the similar thing, but with this hybrid arms. So the way the pipeline works
is you get an RGB image,

we create a 3D reconstruction
using a network called MAST3R. And then of course, there's
a standard image segmentation

network that can
help find objects. This then creates an
occupancy grid, a mental map

of where everything is. Then you make a path. And in planning the path, you
use the a model of the soft arm,

and then it goes
through another network and creates the actuation. And the idea is that
by creating paths

that are separate for the
rigid and the soft part, you can make sure that the rigid
arm is not bumping into anything

or touching anything. But the soft arm, you don't
have that constraint anymore. You can touch and you
can coil around things.

So again, this work
is still going on, but here's some examples
of what we're seeing. So there's a one single camera
at the end of the manipulator

in the soft arm. And we're using that to create
these 3D reconstructions.
